chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will use the normal distribution property of a spreadsheet program to solve for the probability of certain scenarios when investing in Treasury bills.

**a.** To solve this problem, we first need to get the arithmetic mean and the standard deviation for long-term corporate bonds. In this case, the values are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Arithmetic mean}&=6.3\%\\
\text{Standard deviation}&=8.1\%
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have these values, we will use $10%$ as our expected return since we are looking at the probability of going over $10\%$

We will then click on an empty cell in the spreadsheet program, click on **"Insert formula"** then type **NORMDIST**.

Once you have pressed enter, you will be prompted to type the values needed.

Another to do this is by typing $=\text{NORM.DIST()}$ or $=NORMDIST()$ in the cell.

Inside the parentheses, we will enter the values in this order:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(\text{expected value},\text{mean},\text{standard dev},\text{true}) \end{aligned}$$
​
In the case of this problem, we will enter this:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(10,6.3,8.1,\text{true}) \end{aligned}$$
​

After pressing enter, the value will immediately show. In this case, the probability is $0.6761$ which means that there is a $67.61\%$ chance of exceeding $10\%$ return in any given year when investing in long-term corporate bonds.

We will do the same process for $0\%$ by simply changing the expected value in the formula:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(0,6.3,8.1,\text{true}) \end{aligned}$$

This will give us a value of $0.2184$ which means that there is a $21.84\%$ chance of getting $0\%$ or less return in any given year.

**b.** For this problem, we will use $3.4\%$ for the mean and $3.1\%$ for the standard deviation.

In the case of this problem, we will enter this:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(10,3.4,3.1,\text{true}) \end{aligned}$$
​
After pressing enter, the value will immediately show. In this case, the probability is $0.9834$ which means that there is a $98.34\%$ chance of exceeding $10\%$ return in any given year.

We will do the same process for $0\%$ by simply changing the expected value in the formula:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(0,3.4,3.1,\text{true}) \end{aligned}$$

This will give us a value of $0.1364$ which means that there is a $13.64\%$ chance of getting $0\%$ or less return in any given year.

**c.** In order to solve the first part of this question, we will use the same values for long-term corporate bonds but we will use $-2.76\%$ as the expected value. 

In the case of this problem, we will enter this:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(-2.76,6.3,8.1,\text{true})\\[15 pt]
&=0.1317\end{aligned}$$

This means that there is a $13.17\%$ chance that this value will recur at any given year. 
​

For the second part of the problem, we will use the same values for t-bills but we will use $10.56\%$ as the expected value

In the case of this problem, we will enter this:

$$\begin{aligned} &=\text{NORMDIST}(10.56,3.4,3.1,\text{true})\\[15pt]
&=0.9895\end{aligned}$$

This means that there is a $98.95\%$ chance that this value will recur at any given year. 
​
